feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 31 at 3:33PM EDT until August 31 at 5:45PM EDT by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
FFWCTP
The National Weather Service in State College has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... South Central Cambria County in central Pennsylvania... Northwestern Bedford County in south central Pennsylvania... Central Somerset County in south central Pennsylvania...
* Until 545 PM EDT.
* At 333 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Johnstown, Somerset, Windber, Bedford, Belmont, Geistown, Berlin, Friedens, Boswell, Davidsville, Central City, Paint, Jerome, Buffalo Mills, Scalp Level, Acosta, New Centerville, Ogletown, Tire Hill and Cessna.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bedford, PA; Cambria, PA; Somerset, PA

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 31 at 3:32PM EDT by NWS Wilmington OH
entry.summary:
At 331 PM EDT, a strong thunderstorm was located near Piketon, moving east at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and very heavy rain.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Visibility will be poor and hydroplaning is possible.
Locations impacted include... Piketon, Beaver, Wakefield, Givens, Stockdale, Germany, and State Route 335 at State Route 776.
If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a sturdy building.
Motorists should slow down and use extra caution.
To report hazardous weather conditions, go to our website at weather.gov/iln and submit your report via social media, when you can do so safely.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Pike; Scioto

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued August 31 at 2:28PM CDT until September 2 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS North Platte NE
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH FOR THE EASTERN NEBRASKA PANHANDLE MONDAY FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
The National Weather Service in North Platte has issued a Fire Weather Watch, which is in effect from Monday afternoon through Monday evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 204 Eastern Panhandle/Crescent Lake NWR.
* TIMING...Monday afternoon and evening.
* WINDS...South 20 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Around 90.
* LIGHTNING...Not expected.
* IMPACTS...Any fire start will be capable of spreading rapidly and be difficult to control.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Panhandle/Crescent Lake NWR

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH MONDAY EVENING FOR LOW HUMIDITY AND STRONG WINDS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONE 204

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued August 31 at 1:28PM MDT until September 2 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Billings has issued a Fire Weather Watch...which is in effect from Monday afternoon through Monday evening.
* IMPACTS: Low humidities, hot temperatures, strong gusty winds, and increasing thunderstorm activity will create erratic fire behavior and new fire starts.
* AFFECTED AREA: In South Central MT Fire Zone...123.
* COUNTIES AFFECTED: In South Central MT...Park...Sweet Grass. In Southwest MT...Gallatin.
* WIND: Southwest 10 to 20 mph with gusts up to 25 mph.
* THUNDERSTORMS: A few high-based thunderstorms are possible in the late afternoon and evening. Any storms that develop have the potential to produce erratic wind gusts to 40 mph.
* HUMIDITY: 11 to 19 percent.
* TEMPERATURES: Mid 70s at high elevations to the mid 90s in the valleys.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Gallatin National Forest

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH MONDAY EVENING

entry.summary:
* Affected area: Fire Zone 109 (Bitterroot). Fire Zone 110 (Deerlodge/West Beaverhead). Fire Zone 111 (East Beaverhead).
* Impacts: The combination of low humidity and thunderstorm outflow winds may result in critical fire weather conditions, increasing the risk for new and existing fires to spread quickly.

* Minimum humidities: 15 to 20 percent

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 31 at 10:34AM CDT by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
Strong to severe thunderstorms may affect the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness this afternoon and tonight. The storms may produce damaging wind gusts of 40 to 60 mph, small hail, occasional cloud-to-ground lightning, and brief heavy downpours. Thunderstorms could happen as early as 2 PM with the most likely time for thunderstorms between 4 PM and 8 PM.
Now is the time to prepare. Campers should take extra precautions in order to secure campsites and make a plan for severe weather. In case of lightning, sit on your personal floatation devices or sleeping pads to minimize your risk to lightning. For strong winds, try to keep your tent away from large or decayed trees. Monitor NOAA Weather Radio for updates and possible warnings.
entry.cap:areaDesc: North St. Louis; Northern Cook/Northern Lake

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 AM EDT Saturday the stage was 7.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:00 AM EDT Saturday was 7.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 7.8 feet. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 8.0 feet on 10/11/1995. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 31 at 10:17AM EDT until September 6 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Gilchrist, Columbia and Suwannee Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM EDT Saturday the stage was 18.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early Friday afternoon and continue falling to 16.8 feet Saturday, September 07. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 31 at 4:58AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
MODERATE TO HEAVY RAIN CONTINUES THROUGH SATURDAY AFTERNOON, DECREASING THROUGH LATE SATURDAY EVENING. HEAVIEST RAIN WILL CONTINUE TO FAVOR THE CENTRAL PORTION OF THE PANHANDLE. LIGHT RAIN WILL CONTINUE INTO SUNDAY.
ADDITIONAL RAINFALL TOTALS EXPECTED FROM SATURDAY MORNING TO SUNDAY EVENING:
FOR AREAS NEAR PORT ALEXANDER EAST TO PETERSBURG AND WRANGELL, 2 TO 3 INCHES, WITH 2 TO 4 INCHES IN HIGHER ELEVATIONS.
FOR AREAS SOUTH OF SUMNER STRAIT, BETWEEN 1 TO 3 INCHES ARE EXPECTED.
NORTH OF FREDERICK SOUND TO THE ICY STRAIT AREA, BETWEEN 1 TO 2 INCHES ARE EXPECTED.
NORTH OF ICY STRAIT, BETWEEN 0.5 TO 1.5 INCHES ARE EXPECTED.
FOR THE NORTHEAST COAST, NEAR YAKUTAT, UP TO 2 INCHES IS EXPECTED
CHECK THAT SUMP PUMPS ARE OPERATIONAL, AND KEEP GUTTERS CLEAR. ON ROADWAYS, WATCH FOR DEBRIS CLOGGING STREET DRAINS. BOAT OWNERS SHOULD CHECK BILGE PUMPS.
RIVERS AND STREAMS ARE RISING BUT NO MAJOR FLOODING IS EXPECTED AT THIS TIME.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 30 at 4:10PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Ozone Action Day Alert.
WHERE...Douglas, Jefferson, Denver, western Arapahoe, western Adams, Broomfield, Boulder, Larimer, and Weld Counties
WHEN...400 PM Friday August 30 to 400 PM Saturday August 31
IMPACTS...Ozone Action Day Alert is now in effect for the Front Range Urban Corridor. Request to limit driving gas and diesel- powered vehicles is now in effect until at least 4 p.m. Saturday, August 31, 2024. Hot, stagnant weather will allow ozone to reach the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category on Friday and Saturday.For areas included in this advisory that are not expected to reach the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (USG) air quality designation, we request that activities, such as driving non-ZEV vehicles (i.e., gas or diesel), be reduced to lessen the impacts on neighboring air quality. Additional air pollution in this region may directly worsen air quality or contribute to precursors which may also adversely affect air quality. For Colorado air quality conditions, forecasts and advisories, visit: https://www.colorado.gov/airquality/colorado_summary.aspx
HEALTH INFORMATION...Increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms and breathing discomfort in active children and adults and people with lung disease, such as asthma. Active children and adults, and people with lung disease, such as asthma, should reduce prolonged or heavy outdoor exertion.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Boulder, CO; Weld, CO; Adams, CO; Denver, CO; Jefferson, CO; Douglas, CO; Arapahoe, CO; Broomfield, CO; Larimer, CO

cap:parameter.value: OZONE ACTION DAY ALERT FROM 400 PM FRIDAY UNTIL 400 PM SATURDAY
